translated: Saá¹ƒghabhedavastu
Saá¹ƒghabhedavastu
At that time, the five people rose from their seats, bared their right shoulders, touched their right knees to the ground, joined their palms, and said:
World-Honored One!
In what kind of dwellings and bedding should we stay?
The Buddha said:

You may stay in secluded places under trees, in empty rooms, in mountain valleys, in caves, in the open, by the side of grass huts or haystacks, in forests, in charnel grounds, by the water's edge, on spread grass, or on leaves.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us slept without pillows and became ill. The Buddha said:
You may use stone, brick, or wood to make armrests, and use any of the ten kinds of robes to make pillows.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in RÄjagá¹›ha. King BimbisÄra of Magadha had this thought:
World-Honored One, if you come here first, I will donate and build a monastery.
At that time, in RÄjagá¹›ha there was a bamboo grove belonging to Kalanda that was the most excellent.
The World-Honored One knew the king's thoughts and went to the bamboo grove of Kalanda.

The king saw from afar the World-Honored One coming, immediately dismounted from the elephant, took the mat on the elephant's back, folded it into four layers and spread it out, and said to the Buddha:
Please sit on this seat.
The World-Honored One then sat on the seat.
At that time, King BimbisÄra took a golden ewer to offer water to the Buddha and said:
This bamboo grove of Kalanda in RÄjagá¹›ha is the most excellent. I now offer it to the World-Honored One. Please accept it out of compassion.
The Buddha told the king:
You now donate this grove to the Buddha and the monks from the four directions.
Why is it so?

If it is something belonging to the Buddha, or a park, park property, a dwelling, dwelling property, robes, alms bowl, sitting mat, or needle case, all the gods, worldly people, MÄra, BrahmÄ, Å›ramaá¹‡as, and brÄhmaá¹‡as are not able to use it, and should revere it as a stÅ«pa.
The king then said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
I offer this Kalandaka Bamboo Grove to the Buddha and the monks of the four directions out of compassion. Please accept it out of pity for me.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke this verse to encourage him:
Those who offer parks and fruit trees, bridges and boats to ferry people,
Wells and houses on open roads,
Such people's blessings increase day and night;
Those who uphold the precepts and delight in the Dharma, they are born in the good realms.
At that time, King BimbisÄra bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and sat to one side. The World-Honored One used various skillful means to teach the Dharma for the king, causing him to rejoice.
The king, hearing the Buddha's teaching, was delighted, rose from his seat, paid homage to the Buddha, and left.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us came from Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a to the city of RÄjagá¹›ha in the morning. A great elder saw them and asked:
Venerable ones, where did you stay last night?
They replied:
In mountain caves, by the water, under trees, by rocks, or on grass.
The elder asked:
Are there no dwellings?
They replied:
No.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
If you were to build dwellings, would you be allowed to do so?
The bhiká¹£us replied:
The World-Honored One has not yet allowed us to build dwellings.
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
I allow the building of dwellings.
At that time, the elders, hearing that the Buddha allowed the bhiká¹£us to build dwellings, immediately built sixty separate dwellings on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a, fully equipped with everything needed.

He invited the Buddha and the Sangha for a meal the next day and offered them a dwelling place. That night, he prepared many kinds of delicious food and drinks. The next day, he went to inform them that the meal was ready.
In the morning, the World-Honored One put on his robe, took his bowl, and went with 1,250 great bhiká¹£us to the great elder's house, where he sat down in the prepared seat.

At that time, the elder personally served many kinds of delicious food and drinks, satisfying everyone. After the meal, they put away their bowls. The elder took a golden jar of water and offered it to the World-Honored One, saying,

I have built sixty dwelling places on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain, providing everything they need. For the sake of blessings and virtues, for the sake of great sacrifices, and for the sake of being reborn in good destinies, I now offer them to the Buddha and the monks from the four directions. I pray that out of compassion, you will accept them.
At that time, the World-Honored One immediately accepted them and encouraged him with this exhortation:
In order to block off cold and heat, and to protect against various ferocious beasts;
Mosquitoes, gadflies, and poisonous insects, also blocked the rain of disease.
Violent diseases and evil winds, in this way they obtained obstruction;
Upholding the precepts without violation, diligently cultivating the Buddha's teachings.
For the sake of firmness and joy, meditative concentration and insight;
Donating dwellings to the Saá¹…gha, the World-Honored One says is foremost.
At that time, the elder of RÄjagá¹›ha took a low seat in front of the World-Honored One. The World-Honored One used countless skillful means to teach the Dharma for his sake, causing him to rejoice.
After the elder was taught the Dharma, he left his seat and departed.

At that time, King BimbisÄra heard that the World-Honored One had allowed the Saá¹…gha to build dwellings. He wanted to build a great lecture hall in the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove, like the royal residence, with all necessary supplies provided in abundance. The Buddha said:
Allow it to be built.
At that time, there were donors who wanted to build pavilions and houses for the Saá¹…gha. The Buddha said:
Allow it to be built.
At that time, there was a donor who wanted to build a Vimana hall for the Sangha. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to build.
At that time, there was a donor who wanted to build a hall shaped like an elephant for the Sangha. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to build.
There was a donor who wanted to build various halls for the Sangha. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to build.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us wanted to build a hall. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to build. All that is needed according to the method of building a hall is allowed.
When the hall was completed, if there was dust on the ground, it should be plastered. If there was no bedding, one could get sick. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to use the Iriya, Yantamo, Mola, Momao, and Maoji robes, or any of the ten types of robes, to make a ground covering.
If there is still sickness, it is allowed to make a bed, with the five types of beds as above.
They wanted to weave a bed. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to weave.
Except for two kinds of ropes:
leather ropes and hair ropes, the rest can be used to make.
If the rope is not enough, it should be woven loosely through the bed frame.
Those who are sick without bedding on the bed are allowed to make cushions.
They do not know what to make it out of.
The Buddha said:
It is allowed to make it out of grass, wool, or silk floss, or to make a small cushion to be sewn to the four sides of the bed.
If the cushion's edges are torn, it should be repaired.
If the filling is gathered in one place, it should be sewn together.ğŸ”½If the cushion is dirty, a double cushion should be made.
If the double one is dirty, a blanket should be placed on top.
At that time the monks had no pillows. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to make one.
They did not know how to make it.
The Buddha said:
It can be square, round, or triangular.
At that time the Sangha in RÄjagá¹›ha obtained a lot of hemp, and the monks hesitated and did not dare accept it. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to accept it.
To make ropes, bed ropes, wooden bed ropes, if woven into a mattress cover, or to make a floor covering, or to make a rope, or to stuff a mattress.
At that time the monks obtained hemp ropes to weave into beds. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to accept.
At that time, snakes, scorpions, centipedes, and other poisonous insects entered the house. The monks who had not yet overcome desire were frightened when they saw them. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to support the legs of the bed.
At that time the group of six monks made high supports. The Buddha said:
One should not make high supports. The maximum height should be one and a half feet or one cubit.
At that time there was a monk whose robe was not strong enough and had no place to put it. The Buddha said:
It should be folded and placed at the head or back.
The robe fell on top of him when he turned over in his sleep. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to hang it on a rope, a hook, or to make a clothes rack to hang it on.
The robes he usually wore and the robes he did not wear were in one place, and when he took the robes he usually wore, they were in disarray. The Buddha said:
The robes he usually wears and the robes he does not wear should not be placed in one place.
He placed his alms bowl, leather shoes, needle case, and oil container in one place. Other monks saw this and disliked it. The Buddha said:
The bowl and needle case should be placed in one place, and the leather shoes and oil container should be placed in one place.
At that time, the monks suffered from darkness in their rooms. The Buddha said:
You may light lamps. If you need oil, give oil. If you need wicks, give wicks. If you need containers for oil, give containers.
They did not know where to place the lamps.
The Buddha said:
You may place them on the corners of wooden beds or rope beds, on top of jars, or in wall niches. If you are concerned about ants drinking the oil, you should cover it.
If the lamp is not bright, you should raise the wick, and if your hands are soiled with oil, you may use a chopstick. If you are worried about burning the chopstick, you may make it out of iron.
That room had no door and was not secure. Thieves and cowherds took the monks' robes, bowls, needle cases, and sitting mats. The Buddha said:
You may make a door. If you need a door hinge, you may make one. If you are worried about a bad smell inside the door, you may drill a hole in the door panel to let out the air.
If you are worried about snakes, centipedes, or poisonous insects entering through the hole, you may make a curtain or board to block the door.
There was no lock, and thieves and cowherds took the monks' robes, bowls, needle cases, and sitting mats.
The Buddha said:
You may make a lock.
They did not know where to place it.
The Buddha said:
Either on the side, above, or below.
They did not know how to open it.
The Buddha said:
You may drill a hole and make a latch, or make a hook. If you are worried about darkness, you may open a window.
The sound was unimpeded, and thieves and shepherds took the monks' robes, bowls, needle cases, and bedding. The Buddha said:
You should make sound-transmitting panels to block the sound.
They did not know how to make them.
The Buddha said:
You can make them square, round, or shaped like an elephant's ear.
At night they suffered from bats, and during the day they suffered from owls entering. The Buddha said:
You may weave a cage-like screen or make sound-transmitting windows.
At that time, the sound-transmitting panels had no locks, and thieves and shepherds took the monks' robes, bowls, needle cases, and sitting mats. The Buddha said:
You may install locks.
The monks who had broken the precepts pulled on the ropes to open the sound-transmitting panels and took the monks' robes, bowls, needle cases, and sitting mats.
The Buddha said:
You may install a crossbar.
At that time, the group of six monks privately used the Sangha's bedding. The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
One should not privately use the bedding of the saá¹ƒgha.
It is permitted to make a distinguishing mark.
Not knowing what kind of distinguishing mark to make,
the Buddha said:

It is permitted to make the image of MaheÅ›vara, or to make a coiled image, or to make an image of the tendrils of a pomegranate plant, or to make five colors, or to make a lotus flower, or to make a name.
At that time, the group of six monks privately made the saá¹ƒgha's distinguishing mark on their own belongings. The other monks saw it and said:
Elder!
Did not the World-Honored One say:
'The belongings of the saá¹ƒgha should not be privately used?'
They replied:
This is not the saá¹ƒgha's property, it belongs to us.
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
One should not make the saá¹ƒgha's distinguishing mark on one's own belongings. It is permitted to dye one's own belongings to make a distinguishing mark.
Those in the group of six monks made a distinguishing mark, either in the shape of a half-moon or a round distinguishing mark.
They made banners like the sun, banners like wheat roots, banners like a piece of ginger, and banners in the shape of cows. The Buddha said:
It should not be so. It is allowed to make banners like water drops sprinkling the ground, banners like cow dung balls, and banners like wheels.
They moved the fixed bedding in the room to another place. The Buddha said:
It should not be moved. It should be given a name and said:
'This is the bedding in such-and-such person's room.'
At that time there was a monk with a young novice. He wanted to install a partition in the room. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to make.
At that time there was a monk who wanted to open a curved barrier alley in front of the room. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to make.
He wanted to make a back inner room. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to make.
If a door is needed, it is allowed to make one. If a wall is needed, it is allowed to make a wall. If a half-wall is needed, it is allowed to make one.
If a large bed is needed, the Buddha said:
It is allowed to make.

translated: If they need a small bed, they should be allowed to make one. If they need a rope bed, they should be allowed to make one. If they need a small rope bed, they should be allowed to make one. If they need a single sitting bed, they should be allowed to make one. If they need planks or mats, they should be given planks or mats.
At that time, a bhiká¹£u wanted to build a room with eaves on all four sides and install railings on top. He was allowed to do so.
Everything needed to build the room should be given to him.
At the time of the poá¹£adha day, the assembly of monks gathered in large numbers, but the hall was small and could not accommodate them all.
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
Allow it to be made large.
They did not know how to make it.
The Buddha said:
If it is made square, round, long, or in two, three, or four courtyards, it is allowed.
Everything needed to build the large hall should be given.
At that time, the people in the hall each had a bed and could not accommodate each other. The Buddha said:
If the three-year-old or older monks sit together on one bed, if they still cannot sit, they should make a long bed or long plank.
If it still does not accept it, you should make a seat with bound grass.
After making a seat with bound grass, he tore the robe. The Buddha said:
You should wrap the edges with soft grass. If it still does not accept it, you should sprinkle the ground with muddy water, spread sand, or spread grass and tree leaves to sit on.
He and the woman were together on the grass and leaves. The Buddha said:
It should not be so.
He and the woman together spread a robe. The Buddha said:
It should not be so.
He and the woman were together on the robe. The Buddha said:
It should not be so.
He and the woman together went up on a rock. The Buddha said:
It should not be so. If one person cannot move the rock, it is allowed to go up.
He and the woman went up in a boat, suspecting it. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to cross directly, whether sitting, standing, or lying down.
At that time the bhiká¹£us were practicing walking meditation in the open air, and suffered from wind, rain, and sun exposure. The Buddha said:
You should build a walking meditation hall.
They did not know how to build it.
The Buddha said:
You should build it long and wide. Provide everything needed for building the hall.
At that time the senior monk, who was old, sick, and weak, fell down while practicing walking meditation. The Buddha said:
You should tie ropes on both ends and walk along the ropes.
When walking along the ropes, their hands became soft and chapped. The Buddha said:
You should make a handle, or a bamboo tube with a rope threaded through it, and hold it while walking along.
When tired from practicing walking meditation, you should place a bed at both ends.
At that time the bhiká¹£us washed their feet, and the rain fell on the freshly dyed robes, ruining the color. The Buddha said:
You should build a separate foot-washing area.
They needed a water basin and a water pitcher, a foot-washing stone, and a sitting mat. All of these were provided.
The god who was in charge of washing feet caused mud to rain down, dirtying their feet, clothes, and sitting mats. The Buddha said:
You should make a path with stones, bricks, or wood.
At that time, on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain, the water was far away. The Buddha said:
You should make a canal.
When making it, they worried that the canal would collapse. The Buddha said:
You should use stones, bricks, or wood to block both sides.
If it is inside the monastery, you should make a pond.
If the sides of the pond collapse, you should use stones, bricks, or wood to block the four sides, and you should build a roof above it.
If the sides of the pond are muddy, you should place stones, bricks, boards, or crushed stones.
They worried that children would fall into the water. The Buddha said:
You should make a railing.
The water in the pond was hot. The Buddha said:
You should put the water in a jar inside the house during the day and place it outside at night. If the house is muddy, you should make a separate water house.
If the ground is muddy and dirtying the feet, one may place stones, bricks, or gravel. They need a water vessel, so it should be given to them.
They used precious materials to make the vessel. The Buddha said:
One should not use precious materials. One should use iron, copper, or pottery.
The water vessel had no place to be put and was damaged. The Buddha said:
In the water house, make a separate shelf to place it.
At that time the Sangha obtained a conch shell. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to keep it.
Again there was no place to put it. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to place it in the same place as the water vessel.
At that time the World-Honored One was in RÄjagá¹›ha and ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

There was a householder named Sudatta who always liked to give alms to orphans, the poor, and beggars. He was therefore given the nickname AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada (meaning feeder of the orphaned and destitute).
He had fields in RÄjagá¹›ha and every year he would travel from ÅšrÄvastÄ« to RÄjagá¹›ha to inspect his fields.
In RÄjagá¹›ha there was an elder who was his close friend. This elder had decorated his house and invited the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha for a meal the next day.

At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada went to the elder's house. It was the elder's usual practice that whenever AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada came, he would rise to greet him, invite him to sit down, and offer him a seat.
But on this day, he did not rise to greet him, did not invite him to sit down, but only decorated his house for the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha.
When AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada arrived, he asked the elder:
Why have you decorated your house?
Is it for a wedding?
Is it to invite the king?
Is it to hold a great sacrifice?
The elder replied:
I am not getting married, nor am I inviting the king. I wish to hold a great sacrifice and invite the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha of 1,250 people.
That Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama has such a great reputation, he is called:
TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, Bhagavat.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada asked:
Is it really the Buddha?
He replied:
It is really the Buddha.
He asked again and again, and the answer was the same:
It is really the Buddha.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada asked three times, and then asked:
Where is the Buddha?
I now wish to go and pay my respects.
The elder replied:
The Buddha is now staying in the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada looked up at the sun and thought:
Today is not the right time to see the World-Honored One. I can go tomorrow.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada then returned home, thinking of the Buddha in his heart as he slept.
At that time, there was a strange god who was a relative of AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada from the past. Out of compassion and for the sake of benefiting him, he had this thought:
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada!
If you wish to see the World-Honored One, do not have any hindrances and fail to see the Buddha.
He then used his spiritual power to extinguish the darkness and suddenly there was great illumination.
When AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada woke up from sleep and saw the light, he thought it was daytime, so he went to the city gate of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the city gate god saw that AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada wished to see the World-Honored One without any hindrances:
I should now open the gate.
He then opened the gate.
When AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada left the ÅšrÄvastÄ« gate, the god then withdrew his spiritual power, the light suddenly disappeared and it suddenly became dark.
At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada was terrified, his heart trembled and his hair stood on end:
I fear there will be enemies coming to harm me!
At that time, the city gate god saw that AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada was terrified and his heart trembled, so he comforted him, saying:
Do not be afraid!
Do not be afraid!
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
If one were to give a hundred horses, each with a hundred golden reins,
A hundred carriages drawn by young girls,
Adorned with the seven treasures, a hundred white elephants from the Himalayas,
Elephants all with six tusks, and a great heap of gold,
And purple gold sand, the king and the king's offerings,
The elephant ridden by the king, if one were to give such things,ğŸ”½The merit of taking a single step
Is sixteen times greater than that.
The elder should just go forward, going forward there is benefit.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada asked:
Who are you?
He replied:
I am the god of the watchmen.
He thought:
It is unprecedented, a heavenly spirit comforting me.
Then AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada went to the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove.
At that time, the World-Honored One was walking in the open air. Seeing AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada coming from afar, he returned to his seat, sat down, and the Buddha's constant radiance illuminated his body.

At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada saw from afar that the World-Honored One's appearance was upright, his faculties were tranquil, he had attained the supreme state of discipline, and his faculties were firm like a great dragon, also like a clear and pure pond without defilements.
Having seen this, a respectful mind arose in him. With a mind of faith and respect, he went before the Buddha and said:
Did you sleep well?
The World-Honored One replied:
While the world sleeps peacefully, I am different from them.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
All sleep peacefully, those who practice the holy life attain nirvana;
If one does not violate desire, one can be liberated from all bonds.
All attachments are exhausted, and one subdues afflictions;
The mind and body are both extinguished and at peace.
At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada made obeisance to the Buddha before the meal and sat to one side.
At that time, the World-Honored One used various skillful means to teach and transform AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada, causing him to rejoice.
He immediately attained the pure Dharma-eye while sitting, saw the Dharma, attained the Dharma, and gave rise to a mind of disgust towards the supreme fruit. He said to the World-Honored One:
I now take refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, and become a Buddhist upÄsaka.
From now on, for the rest of my life, I will not kill, and so forth, up to not drinking alcohol.
I only wish that the World-Honored One, together with the saá¹…gha, would accept my invitation to spend the ninety-day summer retreat.
The Buddha said:
I have already accepted King BimbisÄra's invitation.
He then said again:
Please accept next year's invitation.
The Buddha said:
I have already accepted King BimbisÄra's invitation.
He said again:
Venerable!
Please accept the invitation for the following year.
The Buddha replied:
If there is such a place, pure and free from disturbance, without evil beasts, and secluded from human habitation, suitable for sitting in meditation, the Tathagata will stay in such a place.
He then said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I have understood. I will know the time myself.
I only wish that the World-Honored One and the Sangha will accept my invitation for a meal tomorrow.
At that time, the World-Honored One silently accepted the invitation.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ika rose from his seat, bowed at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him, and left.
At that time, King BimbisÄra heard that AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ika had invited the Buddha and the Sangha for a meal the next day, so he sent a message saying:
You are a guest here. The Sangha is large, with 1,250 people. You do not need to prepare offerings. I will do it for you.
At that time, someone was sent to reply to the king, saying:
This is already an offering.
It is not necessary. I will prepare it myself.
At that time, the great elder of Magadha heard that AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada had invited the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha for a meal the next day, so he went to him and said:
You are a guest here, and the Saá¹…gha is so numerous. You should not be bothered with the preparations. I will make the arrangements for you.
He replied:
Elder!
This is already an offering.
It is not necessary.
I will make the arrangements myself.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada then returned home and prepared various delicious foods during the night. When it was dawn, he announced that the meal was ready.
The World-Honored One put on his robe, took his bowl, and together with a Saá¹…gha of 1,250 bhiká¹£us went to AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's house, sat down in the prepared seats,

and AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada personally served various delicious foods, making offerings to the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha until they were all satisfied. After the meal, they put away their bowls, and he took a low seat and sat before the Buddha.
At that time, the World-Honored One used countless skillful means to expound the Dharma for AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada, guiding and transforming him, causing him to rejoice.
After expounding the Dharma, he rose from his seat and departed.
At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada returned from RÄjagá¹›ha to the country of ÅšrÄvastÄ«. He went to villages and towns, proclaiming everywhere with these words:

Plant gardens and orchards in empty places, set up ponds and wells, and build bridges and boats. The Buddha has already appeared in the world. He has now accepted my invitation to spend the summer retreat in ÅšrÄvastÄ«. He will come along this road to ÅšrÄvastÄ«, enabling you to obtain immeasurable blessings.
Having arrived in ÅšrÄvastÄ«, he had this thought:

Now, in what place is it neither too close nor too far, with a level and spacious area for coming and going to enjoy the scenery, without the noise of crowds during the day and the sounds of the night, and without mosquitoes, gadflies, flies, bees, or poisonous insects?
I shall buy it and build a monastery for the Buddha.
He then had this thought:

Prince Jeta has a beautiful garden in the country of Shravasti, not too far, where one can walk and view the scenery. The ground is level and open, with no noise during the day and no sounds at night, and no mosquitoes, gadflies, or poisonous insects.
I should now go to Prince Jeta and ask to buy it.
He then went to the prince and said:
Do you know that the Buddha has appeared in the world?
He has accepted my invitation to spend the summer retreat in Shravasti. I will give you a hundred thousand gold coins for the garden.
The prince said:
I will not sell it.
He then repeated his request as above:
Please give me the garden, and I will give you two hundred, three hundred, four hundred thousand gold coins.
The prince said:
Even if you cover the ground with gold coins without leaving any space, I still will not give it to you.
Anathapindada said:
You have already set the price.
You may accept it.
The prince said:
What is the agreed price?
He replied:
Didn't you just say to cover the ground with gold coins without leaving any gaps? Isn't that the agreed price?
The gods can look at the king's old regulations.
He then looked at the king's old regulations and said, Since you have already said that, it is the agreed price. He then said:
Elder!
Do as you wish.
At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada returned home and ordered people to bring out many gold coins to cover Jeta Grove. There was still a small area of ground that had not been covered with gold.
Jeta saw this and thought:
This is not an ordinary person, nor is he an ordinary field of merit, yet he can make AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada be so unsparing of his precious treasures.
He then said:
Elder, stop!
Do not cover it with gold anymore. I myself wish to offer the remaining ground to the World-Honored One.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada said:
You may do as you wish.
At that time, the World-Honored One left RÄjagá¹›ha with 1,250 bhiká¹£us, traveling through the human realm to the country of Vá¹›ji, and then further to VaiÅ›ÄlÄ«.
At that time, the group of six bhiká¹£us went ahead of the Buddha to take the rooms, for their preceptors, co-preceptors, teachers, co-teachers, and for their acquaintances and close friends.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana arrived later.
The Buddha said:
Whose rooms are these?
The group of six bhiká¹£us said:
They are the rooms for our preceptors, co-preceptors, teachers, co-teachers, and acquaintances and close friends.
ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana did not get rooms to stay in, so they stayed on the outer slope.
After the night passed, ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana went to where the World-Honored One was, bowed their heads at his feet, and then stood to one side.
The World-Honored One, knowing the reason, deliberately asked:
Did ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana sleep well?
They replied:ğŸ”½We did not sleep well.
Comfortable.
The World-Honored One asked:
Where did you stay?
He replied:
On the outer terrace.
For what reason is it so?
He then fully explained the reasons to the Buddha.
At that time, the World-Honored One, because of this incident, assembled the bhiká¹£us and said:
Who do you think should receive the first seat, the first water, the first food, rising to welcome and see off, paying homage and showing respect, and kind inquiries?
Some said:
One who has left the household life from a great family.
Some said:
One with a handsome appearance.
Some said:
One who is in seclusion.
Some said:
One who begs for food.
Some said:
One who wears discarded clothes.
Some said:
One who does not eat after the ritual of leaving leftovers.
Some said:
One who eats in one sitting.
Some said:
One who eats one meal.
Some said:
One who lives in a charnel ground.
Some said:
One who sits in the open.
Some said:
One who sits under a tree.
Some said:
One who always sits.
Some said:
One who sits wherever one happens to be.
Some said:
One who has three robes.
Some said:
One who can chant.
Some said:
One who is learned.
Some said:
A Dharma master.
Some said:
One who upholds the precepts.
Some said:
One who practices meditation.
The Buddha told the monks:
You should listen well!
Whether to give or not to give.
Long ago, there were three close friends:
An elephant, a monkey, and a partridge, who lived near a nyagrodha tree.
They thought:
We should not live together without respecting each other and looking down on each other. We should push for the order of seniority and respect each other according to rank.
If someone is older, they should be respected, revered, and offered to.
After establishing this rule, we will live together in the forest.
The monkeys and partridges asked the elephant:
How long is your memory?
The elephant said:
I remember when I was small, this nyagrodha tree touched my navel when I walked.
The elephant and partridge asked the monkey:
How long is your memory?
The monkey replied:
I remember when I was small, this nyagrodha tree reached my head when I raised my hand.
The elephant said to the monkey:
You are older than me.
The elephant and monkey asked the partridge:
How long is your memory?
He replied:
'I remember on the right side of the Snow Mountain there was a large nyagrodha tree. I ate the fruit there and came out, and then this tree grew.'
He thought like this:
'The partridge is many years older than me.'
Then the elephant put the monkey on its head, the monkey put the partridge on its shoulder, and they traveled together through the human world.
From village to village, from city to city, they spoke the Dharma, saying:
'Those who respect the elderly are able to abide in the Dharma.
In this life they have a good reputation and in the future they will be reborn in a good realm.'
At that time, when the partridge spoke this Dharma, people all followed it, and the Dharma teachings spread.
You have gone forth in my Dharma and Vinaya, and you should respect each other like this. In this way the Buddha Dharma can spread.
From now on, I allow you to respect and pay homage to the senior monks according to your age, and to greet them and inquire about their well-being.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard the Buddha's teaching. The bhiká¹£us of all ages followed each other in respecting the elders. They said to the laypeople,
You are older than I am.
The Buddha said:
You should not pay homage to laypeople. You should pay homage to those who should be paid homage, but you should not pay homage to all women.
Those who have received the full precepts before should not pay homage to those who have received the full precepts after.

Those who have committed a pÄrÄjika offense, those who have violated a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, those who have received the precepts with a thieving mind, those who have destroyed the two paths, those who are paá¹‡á¸akas, those who have killed their father, those who have killed their mother, those who have killed an arhat, those who have disrupted the harmony of the Saá¹ƒgha, those who have maliciously drawn blood from the body of the Buddha, those who are non-humans, those who are animals, those who have two sexual organs, those who have been expelled, those who have been expelled for a serious offense, and those who should be expelled for a serious offense - all those whose words are not in accordance with the Dharma should not be paid homage.
To which people should one pay homage?
Novice nuns should pay homage to senior novice nuns, novice monks, female novices, fully ordained nuns, and fully ordained monks, and to the stupas of all these people.
If a young novice monk should pay homage to senior novice monks, novice nuns, female novices, fully ordained nuns, and fully ordained monks, and to the stupas of all these people.

Junior female novices should pay homage to senior female novices, fully ordained nuns, fully ordained monks, and to the stupas.ğŸ”½Younger fully ordained nuns should pay homage to senior fully ordained nuns, fully ordained monks, and to the stupas.
Junior fully ordained monks should pay homage to senior fully ordained monks, and to the stupas of senior fully ordained monks.
All gods, worldly people, demons, Brahma kings, ascetics, and Brahmins should pay homage to the Tathagata, the World-Honored One, and to the stupas.
Since the World-Honored One has taught that one should pay homage to stupas,
They then bowed to the white-robed ones' stupas and temples. The Buddha said:
You should not bow to the white-robed ones' stupas and temples.
Since they were not allowed to bow to the white-robed ones' stupas and temples, they circumambulated them counterclockwise. The gods who guarded the stupas and temples became angry.
The Buddha said:
You should go in the direction you came from. You should not deliberately circumambulate counterclockwise.
The bhiká¹£us thought like this:
Should the novice monks be in order according to their age since birth or according to the years since leaving the household life?
The Buddha said:
They should be in order according to their age since birth.
If their age since birth is the same, they should be in order according to the years since leaving the household life.
The bhiká¹£us arrived first, and later a great bhiká¹£u came.
They moved the novice monks to the front in one night. The Buddha said:
You should not move them. You should not get up. You are allowed to sit in the middle.
Since they were sitting in the middle, they moved again, causing the assembly to become noisy. The Buddha said:
Those who come later should sit in the lower seats.
Since they sat in the lower seats, they sat below the laypeople. The Buddha said:
It should not be so.
They then sat below the novice monks. The Buddha said:
It should not be so. They should sit below the fully ordained monks.
They did not participate in the later retreat and counted the day they received full ordination as a year. The Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The preceptor and teacher should teach the time of receiving the precepts. The teaching should be like this:
Whether it is winter, spring, or summer, you have obtained so many days, one month, half a month, one day, before the meal, after the meal, up to the time of measuring the shadow.
The group of six monks saw the senior monk coming in the laypeople's house but did not stand up. This is not the Sangha's land. The Buddha said:
It should not be so. You should stand up.
If one is by the water's edge, under a tree, by a rock, on grass, or on a boat, one should not get up to avoid the senior monk, saying:
This is not the Sangha's land.
The Buddha said:
One should get up.
At that time there was a householder who built a dwelling for the Sangha, but no one lived in it. He said this:
The wealthy elders with abundant wealth and treasures built this dwelling for the Sangha, but the monks of the ÅšÄkya clan live in it. We are poor, so who will live here?
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
The Sangha should give a white two-part karman to the monks. It should be given like this.
In the assembly, appoint someone capable of performing the karman as above, and make this announcement:
'Venerable Sangha, listen!
Now the Sangha will give this dwelling to monk so-and-so to take care of.
If the Sangha is ready, the Sangha approves.
Announce it like this.
'Venerable Sangha, listen!
This room belongs to monk so-and-so.
Which elder monks agree that the Sangha should give this room to monk so-and-so to repair? Those who agree remain silent. Those who do not agree, speak up.
The Sangha has agreed to give this room to monk so-and-so to repair. The Sangha approves, because of their silence. This is how it should be done.
At that time the monks wanted to build a room. The Buddha said:
I allow it.
They wanted to level the ground. The Buddha said:
I allow it.
If there are stones, tree roots, or thorns, they should be removed;
if there are pits, ditches, or low-lying areas, they should be filled in;
if there is concern about water, a dike should be built;
if there is concern that the land may have an owner or cause other disputes, it should be decided clearly;
if there are large tree stumps or stones, they should be dug out.ğŸ”½If they cannot be removed, they should be burned;
if they cannot be removed, they should be burned and then watered with brine.
If you were to break it open with a stone hammer,
If it is difficult to break, use an iron hammer to break it out.
If it is still impossible to remove, dig a large pit beside it and bury it deeply.
If one wants to level the ground, one should plow it and grind it flat.
Who should level it?
The Buddha said:
Either a bhiká¹£u, a novice monk, a monk's attendant, or a lay devotee.
If they need bricks, they are allowed to make them, either by themselves or by instructing others to make them.
If they need a brick mold, they are allowed to give it.
If mud sticks to the brick mold, the Buddha said:
One should put a worn-out cloth in the water and wipe the four sides with it.
If there is grass at the brick-making site, the Buddha said:
One should go to a place without grass. If the bricks are not dry, one should turn them over.
If, when turning them over, one cuts grass, it is not an offense.
If the bricks are not even, one should trim them to make them even.
If they are dry, one should stack them.
If it is soaked by rain, you should cover it above.ğŸ”½If it is blown up by the wind, you should cover it above and press it down with wood or stones.
If you are worried about cattle, sheep, and other animals eating it, you should cover the grass above with mud.
If you need a door on the mud, you should give it a door.
They made images of dragons and snakes on the door, the Buddha said:
You should not make such images. You are allowed to make images of jujube trees, vines, or lotus flowers.
They wanted to make flower images on the door, the Buddha said: You are allowed to do so.
They made images of soldiers and horses, the Buddha said:
You should not make such images. You are allowed to use purple, vermilion, or five colors.
They leaned on the colors to relax.
The Buddha said:
You should not lean on them.
The senior monks, the sick, and the monks who came from afar were not comfortable without leaning on them. The Buddha said:
You are allowed to use grass leaves, tree bark, or any of the ten kinds of robes to lean on your back.
Those monks lay down on their sides with their cheeks on the ground during the day in places where many people were, and the laypeople saw this and all criticized them, saying:
The Å›ramaá¹‡as, sons of ÅšÄkya, claim to be enlightened, yet they lie down on their sides with their cheeks on the ground during the day?
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not do that.
Those senior monks who were old and sick and had come from far away were exhausted from not sleeping during the day. The Buddha said:
Allow them to enter the room, close the door, and sleep.
They drove out the sick monks, and the Buddha said:
You should not drive out the sick monks, nor should you leave.
The group of six monks relied on their illness to avoid the senior monks. The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not do that.
Those sick monks lived in the large rooms on the upper floors, and their urine, feces, and spittle polluted and stank, making it impure.
The Buddha said:
Sick monks should not live in upper stories or large rooms, but in small rooms or separate huts.
When those sick monks were unable to reach the toilet, the Buddha said:
You should dig a hole nearby for them to urinate and defecate in.ğŸ”½If they were unable to leave the room, the Buddha said:
You should place a chamber pot in the room.
If they were unable to get up from the bed, the Buddha said:
You should make a hole in the bed and place the chamber pot underneath.
They spat in the room and soiled the floor. The Buddha said:
You should not do that.
When those senior monks who were old and sick got up frequently, they became exhausted. The Buddha said:
You should make a spittoon.
When they picked up lice in a crowded place and discarded them on the ground, the Buddha said:
You should not do that.
When those senior monks who were old and sick got up frequently to discard lice, they became exhausted. The Buddha said:
You may use a container made of wool, cotton, or cloth, or fill it with cotton.
If the lice crawl out, you should make a tube to hold them.
If they use precious materials to make the tube, the Buddha said:

You should not use precious materials to make the tube. You may use ivory, bone, iron, copper, lead, tin, bamboo, reed, wood to make the tube. If the lice crawl out, you should make a lid to cover it.
If they use precious materials to make the lid, the Buddha said:
You should not use precious materials to make it. You may use ivory, bone, up to wood to make it.
If there is no place to put it, you may tie it with a thread under the bed leg.
At that time, the monks were assigning rooms. A monk got a dilapidated room. He thought:
Either let me repair it.
He did not take it. The Buddha said:
You should accept it. According to your ability, you should repair it to a certain extent.
If they want to repair the room, the Buddha said:
You should provide all the necessary items for their treatment.
At that time, the World-Honored One traveled among the people of Vaishali, passed through the country of Vatsa, and arrived in the country of Shravasti, together with 1,250 bhikshus.

At that time, Anathapindika heard that the World-Honored One had come from there to Shravasti, and immediately rode in a carriage to welcome him. Seeing the Buddha from afar, he got down from the carriage and went to where the Buddha was. He bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and then stood to one side.

At that time, the World-Honored One used countless skillful means to expound the Dharma for Anathapindika in various ways, guiding and transforming him, causing him to rejoice. He then said to the World-Honored One:
I only wish that you would accept my invitation for a meal tomorrow and stay at Jetavana.
The World-Honored One silently accepted.

Knowing that the Buddha had accepted the invitation, Anathapindika paid homage and left. He returned home and prepared various kinds of rich and delicious food that very night. In the morning, he went to announce that the meal was ready.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The World-Honored One put on his robe, took his bowl, went to the dining hall, and sat down at the seat prepared.
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada personally served various delicious foods to the Buddha and the saá¹…gha of monks, making them feel satisfied.
After putting down the bowl, he took the golden pitcher and poured water, and said to the Buddha:
I offer this Jeta Grove to the World-Honored One. Please accept it.
The Buddha said:
Householder!
You should offer this grove to the Buddha and the saá¹…gha of the four directions.
Why is it so?
Householder!

If it is the World-Honored One's grove, grove property, dwelling, dwelling property, robe, bowl, sitting mat, or needle case, it is a stÅ«pa. All gods, humans, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, MÄras, or BrahmÄs are not able to use it.
He then offered the grove to the Buddha and the saá¹…gha of the four directions according to the teaching.
I only wish that the World-Honored One, out of compassion, would accept it.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse of exhortation:
Planting gardens and fruit trees, building bridges and boats,
Providing wells and houses in the wilderness,
Such people will have their blessings increase day and night,
Always upholding the precepts in accordance with the Dharma, and later will be reborn in a good realm.

Then AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and sat to one side. The World-Honored One used countless skillful means to teach the Dharma in various ways, enlightening and delighting him. AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada was delighted upon hearing the Dharma, paid homage, and left.
At that time, cows and sheep came into the Jeta Grove without restraint. The Buddha said:
Dig a moat to block them.
The senior monks, who were old and sick, were unable to cross it when walking. The Buddha said:
Allow the building of bridges.
But they did not know how to build them.
Use planks or wood, or set up ropes to connect them.
When the senior sick and old monks were crossing the bridge, their legs slipped and they fell to the ground. The Buddha said:
You should tie ropes on both sides for them to hold onto while crossing. If they still fall to the ground while holding the ropes, you should install railings on both sides.
If the moat is not secure, you should build a fence.

If there is no gate, you should make a gate. If the fence is not strong, you should pound the walls. You should provide everything needed for building the walls. If it is not secure, you should build a multi-storied pavilion.
At that time, Prince Jeta wanted to build a very expensive heavy gate for Jetavana. The Buddha said:
You may build it.
At that time, the trees in Jetavana were not good. The Buddha said:
You may plant three kinds of trees:
Flower trees, fruit trees, and leaf trees.
At that time, the senior monks who were well-known in ÅšrÄvastÄ« had a heat illness after eating and returning to Jetavana. The Buddha said:

You may use grass or tree leaves as a screen. Among the ten kinds of robes, you may use any one robe as a screen to make shade. If it is still hot, you should plant the three kinds of trees mentioned above along the side of the steps.
At that time, the Jeta Grove was far from water. You may dig a canal to lead water.
They complained that the canal was damaged. The Buddha said:
You may use grass to block it. If the grass rots, you may also use bricks, stones, or wood to block it.

If you build a well, you may use everything needed for the well.ğŸ”½If the well water leaks out and the container breaks, you may use wood to press down on the four sides and place the container in the middle.
If it still breaks, you may fill it with a wool bag.ğŸ”½If it still breaks, you may make it with leather.
If the rope breaks, you may make it with leather.
The monks were not skilled in making and suffered from sore hands. You may use a wheel to pull it.
If the wheel hole breaks, you may make it with iron.
If you suffer from the water returning and entering the well, you may use stones, bricks, or wood to block the four sides.
If there is mud in the washing place, bricks and stones should be placed there.
If there is a danger of small children falling into the well, fences should be made of wood, pottery, bricks, or stones.
If a muddy vessel is pulled and the rope breaks and falls into the well, it should be hooked out with a hook.
They had no place to store the well rope, so the Buddha said:
You should make a rack nearby and place it on top.
At that time, there was no bathhouse in Jetavana, so the Buddha said:
You should build one.
They did not know how to build it,
so the Buddha said:
You should build it either square, round, or octagonal.
They built it in front of the house, so the Buddha said:
You should not do that. You should build it in a secluded place on the side.
They were cold in the bathhouse, so the Buddha said:
You should make a door.ğŸ”½ They were uncomfortable with the smoke, so the Buddha said:
You should open a hole on top.ğŸ”½ They were uncomfortable with the darkness, so the Buddha said:
You should open a window.ğŸ”½ They were uncomfortable with the mud, so the Buddha said:
You should make a bathing platform with stones, bricks, or wood.
If they are worried about getting their feet dirty, they should make a platform with bricks or stones.
If the wooden head is uneven, they should carve it to look like a dog's tooth to press down on.
At that time, the group of six monks closed the door when the senior monk wanted coolness and opened the door when he wanted warmth.
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should follow what the Sangha wants and give it to them.
Those six monks entered the bathhouse first and sat in good places, and when the senior monk came in later there was no place.
The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should sit in order.
Since the senior monk did not enter that place, the Buddha said:
The next seat should be sat on.
If the face is smoked, they should cover the face with something.ğŸ”½If the head is hot, they should cover it.
If the back is hot, they should cover it.
If the body is dirty and smelly, they should wash it with mud.
The bhiká¹£us were doubtful and did not dare to put the incense in the mud. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to put it in.
If the floor of the bathhouse is hot, you should sprinkle it to cool it down.
They bathed together with laypeople and looked at each other's tails, saying that so-and-so was long and so-and-so was coarse.
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not bathe together with laypeople. If you praise the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, it is allowed to bathe.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us hung their robes on the ground, and the rain soaked them. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to hang them on a wall, a hook, or a clothes rack.
They were troubled by the smoke and dirt staining their robes. The Buddha said:
It is allowed to build a separate robe house.
They bared their bodies and rubbed each other's bodies. The Buddha said:
You should not do that.
They bared their bodies and rubbed the bodies of those who were not bared. The Buddha said:
You should not do that.
The naked ascetics were afraid and hesitant, not daring to rub the bodies of the naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It is allowed.
The naked ascetics shaved the heads of the naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics shaved the heads of the non-naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The non-naked ascetics shaved the heads of the naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics chewed willow twigs, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics washed their hands, feet, and face, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics ate, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics urinated and defecated, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics paid homage to the naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The naked ascetics bowed to the non-naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The non-naked ascetics bowed to the naked ascetics, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics walked, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
The naked ascetics paced back and forth, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
At that time, the bathhouse in Jetavana was far from water. The Buddha said: Allow the construction of canals and wells as above.
If there is little water, a large canal should be built.
The monks suffered from sore hands while drawing water. The Buddha said: Allow the installation of a pulley.
They did not know where to store the water.
Allow it to be placed in a jar.
During the rainy season, they suffered from their clothes getting wet. The Buddha said: Allow the construction of a roof over the well.
At that time, the monks drew water naked. When they saw women coming, they felt embarrassed and sat down. The monks told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us bathed in springs, canals, and ponds. The dragon girls became angry and complained. The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, who said:
It should not be so.

I allow four kinds of covered and concealed bathing: in a place with walls and barriers, in a place with trees and grass barriers, in a place where the body is concealed by water, or in a place where the body is concealed by clothes.
Those who bathe in the upper three places, if they need anything, are allowed to take and give to each other.
Those who conceal their bodies with clothes are all in accordance with the Dharma.ğŸ”½One may engage in bathing activities. If there is little water, one should open up a large water area.
If there is a problem with water leaking down a lot, one should make a smaller leak area on the side.
The bhiká¹£us caught a cold from bathing in the open air. The Buddha said:
I allow you to build a small bathhouse separately.
If you have a problem with the ground being muddy, you may place bricks, stones, wood, crushed stones, or sand. If it is old mud, you should drain the water.
At that time the monks warmed water in the open air, and the rain wet their robes. The Buddha said:
You should build a warm water house.
At that time the monks stored firewood in the open air, and the rain wet it. The Buddha said:
You should build a firewood storage house.
At that time a monk watched food being cooked in the open air, and the rain wet his robes and sprinkled the food and utensils of the pure persons. The Buddha said:
You should build a pure food kitchen house.
At that time the monks were invited to a layperson's house for a meal, and on the way they encountered rain that wet their robes. The Buddha said:
You should build a separate monastery in the village.
At that time the monks defecated and urinated in the open air, and a woman saw them. The monks quickly got up, and because they did not finish defecating, they became ill.
The Buddha said:
You should build a toilet house.
They built one large toilet, and many people stood waiting to use it. The Buddha said:
You should make many places.
If people can see each other when they go to the toilet, you should make a partition.
The senior sick monks fell down when they got up from defecating and urinating. The Buddha said, You should install railings on the sides.
They wiped their anuses everywhere, on the corners of the walls, on rocks, or on grass. The Buddha said,
You should not do that. You should make a separate washing place.
They urinated everywhere, making the ground muddy. The Buddha said,
You should not do that.
You should urinate in one place on the side.
If it still becomes muddy, you should make a separate place for urinating.
They did not know how to make it.
The Buddha said,

You should dig a hole, put a stone at the bottom, and place a pot on it. Open the bottom of the pot to let the urine flow out. Place wood on both sides of the pot. If it smells bad, make a cover to cover it.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us were walking in the open air, and there were snakes, scorpions, centipedes, and millipedes. The bhiká¹£us who had not yet abandoned desire were frightened when they saw them. The Buddha said:
Allow the construction of a suspended walkway.
They did not know how to build it.
The Buddha said:
Below, erect pillars and above, install boards and wooden galleries to walk on.
If you suffer from wind, rain, and sun exposure, allow the construction of a roof to cover it.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in KoÅ›ala.
The group of six bhiká¹£us lit a fire in a well-colored, beautifully decorated room, and the smoke stained the room and bedding. The Buddha said:
You should not do that.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us suffered from the cold in winter. Allow the lighting of fires in the open air for warmth.
The bhiká¹£us sitting in the open air suffered from a cold back. Allow the burning of fires outside until the smoke is gone, and then bring the charcoal into the room.
If it is not spacious enough, a separate fire hall should be built.
They did not know how to build it.
The Buddha said:
You may build it in any shape, round or long.
They placed the hearth in various places, the Buddha said:
You should not do that.
You may place the hearth in the middle.
At that time the monks obtained a hearth with a wheel, the Buddha said:
You may keep it.
They did not know who should push it,
the Buddha said:
A novice monk, or a monk, or someone who tends the monastery.
The monks were not used to blowing on the fire, and got sick from blowing on the fire, the Buddha said:
You may make a tube to blow with.
They used precious substances to make the tube, the Buddha said:
You may not use precious substances.
You may use ivory, horn, bone, copper, iron, reed grass tubes, bamboo, or wood to make it.
If you suffer from the mouth of the tube burning, you may attach an iron plate to it.
If firewood and fire fall into the hearth, you may put them on top.
If you suffer from burning your hands, make tongs.
They used precious materials to make tongs, the Buddha said:
This is not appropriate.
You are allowed to use bone, ivory, horn, copper, iron, and wood to make them.
If you suffer from a burning head, you are allowed to use copper or iron plates.
They wanted to gather fire to make a fire pit or to plant fire, You should make a fire pit and place the fire there.
If you are afraid the fire will go out, cover it with ash.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us washed their faces, hands, and feet with cold water and suffered from the cold. The Buddha said:
You are allowed to wash with warm water.
They did not know how to heat the water.
The Buddha said:
Fill a water pot with water and place it by the fire.
If there are many water pots or they do not fit by the fire, you should set up three poles and hang the pots on them to heat the water.
The large pots hinder the fire, you should hang them with ropes.
If the rope burns, put the rope in a tube. If the tube burns, smear it with mud.
When pouring out the water, the tube broke. The Buddha said:
You should use another vessel to scoop it out.
When pouring water from the water pot, if you are worried about wasting water, you should make a water-pouring tube.
If the rope is cut, attach an iron ring on top.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us suffered from cold when washing their feet in the winter. The Buddha said:
You should place a foot-washing basin and foot-washing implements in the house for washing your feet. You should be given what is necessary for washing your feet.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us applied oil to their feet early in the morning and entered the village to beg for food. A woman bowed by touching their feet, and the oil soiled her hands that held the bhiká¹£us' alms bowls. Other bhiká¹£us disliked it.
The bhiká¹£us told the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You should not apply oil to your feet early in the morning and enter the village to beg for food.
The bhiká¹£us' feet were cracked. You are allowed to apply oil to the heels and soles of your feet, up to the toes.
At that time, the saá¹ƒgha obtained a single-storied building. The Buddha said:
You are allowed to live in it.
At that time, the World-Honored One went from Magadha to the city of Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a.
At that time, the group of six monks used male and female figures and embroidered patterns to decorate the hall, the Buddha said:
It should not be so.
You are allowed to use other miscellaneous colored bird and animal patterns.
At that time, the Sangha obtained a double-storied building with two rooms and one door. The Buddha said:
You are allowed to live there.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in the country of Shravasti.
At that time, Ananda obtained a separate room. The Buddha said:
You are allowed to keep it.
At that time, Rahula was staying in the Nalin Grove.
At that time, there was a householder in Nalin who, without being urged by others, spontaneously built a dwelling and offered it to Rahula.
After Rahula had stayed in this dwelling and gone out for a while, the householder heard that Rahula had stayed in the dwelling and gone out for a while, and then offered the dwelling to the Sangha.
At that time, the World-Honored One was traveling among the people of Magadha and arrived at the Nalin Grove, where he sat on a seat that was prepared for him.

At that time, RÄhula heard that the householder had donated the dwelling to the saá¹…gha, so he went to where the World-Honored One was, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, then sat to one side and said to the Buddha:
There is a householder in NÄlandÄ who did not seek advice from anyone, but spontaneously built a dwelling and donated it to me.
After I stayed in the dwelling and went out to wander among the people, the householder then donated the dwelling to the saá¹…gha again.
The Buddha told RÄhula:
Allow you to go to that householder and say to him:
'Do you not see any faults in me?
Are my words or actions impure or non-Å›ramaá¹‡a-like?'
At that time, RÄhula accepted the World-Honored One's instruction, went to the householder, and fully told the householder the above words. The householder replied:
I do not see any faults in you that are to be reproached, nor any non-Å›ramaá¹‡a-like words or actions that are impure.
At that time, RÄhula went to where the World-Honored One was, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, sat to one side, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I have fully explained to the householder what you instructed me to say.
The householder replied to me, saying:
'I do not see any faults to be reproached in you, nor is there any impurity in the practice of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, whether in your speech or bodily actions.'
At that time, the World-Honored One, for this cause and condition, assembled the assembly of bhiká¹£us and said:
You should listen well!
It is an improper offering, an improper acceptance, and an improper dwelling.
It is a proper offering, a proper acceptance, and a proper dwelling.
What is an improper offering, an improper acceptance, and an improper dwelling?
If a person himself happily makes a dwelling and offers it to one person, and then again offers it to many people, this is an improper offering, an improper acceptance, and an improper dwelling.
Having offered it to one person, and then offering it to the saá¹ƒgha is also like this.
After giving to one person, the Sangha splits into two factions. Giving to one's own faction is also like this.
After giving to one person, giving to the other faction is also like this.
Or someone joyfully wishes to build a dwelling, gives it to many people, and then gives it to the Sangha. This is an improper giving, improper receiving, and improper dwelling.
After giving to many people, the Sangha splits into two factions. Giving to one's own faction is also like this.
After giving to many people, giving to the other faction is also like this.
After giving to many people, giving to one person is also like this.ğŸ”½After building a dwelling and giving it to the Sangha, giving it to others is also like this.
After building a dwelling and giving it to one's own faction is also like this.
After building a dwelling and giving it to the other faction is also like this.
This is an improper giving, improper receiving, and improper dwelling.
What is proper giving, proper receiving, and proper dwelling?
If someone happily builds a dwelling themselves and gives it to one person, this is a proper gift, proper acceptance, and proper dwelling.
Giving to many people, giving to the Sangha, and giving to the two parts of the Sangha is also like this.
This is a proper gift, proper acceptance, and proper dwelling.
At that time, the World-Honored One was traveling among the people of Kashi with five hundred bhikkhus.
At that time, there were four old bhikkhus in the country of Kalinga:
Ashvajit, Bhadrika, Gavampati, and Kaulita.

When the four bhikkhus heard that the World-Honored One was traveling among the people with five hundred people and would come to Kalinga, they said, The World-Honored One has two disciples, Shariputra and Maudgalyayana, who will come here. They may drive us out of this dwelling place.
We might as well choose the best rooms for the World-Honored One, and divide the rest into four parts as our private property.
The monastery, monastery property, rooms, and room property were made the first share for the monks;
Jars, bottles, pots, cauldrons, axes, chisels, lamp stands, and miscellaneous heavy objects were made the second share for the monks;
Rope beds, wooden beds, large cushions, small cushions, bedding, and miscellaneous items were made the third share for the monks;
The remaining trees, bamboos, grasses, flowers, fruits, and leaves were made the fourth share for the monks.
At that time, the four monks selected the best room for the World-Honored One, and the rest were divided into four shares as above.
At that time, the World-Honored One traveled among the people of the KÄÅ›i country, arrived at KuÅ›inagara, sat on the prepared seat, and told ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana:
Go and tell those old monks, 'The World-Honored One is coming to the KÄÅ›i country with five hundred monks. You should now prepare bedding for the monks.'
ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana accepted the World-Honored One's instructions and went to the old monks' quarters to arrange bedding as instructed.
Those monks replied:

The World-Honored One is the master of the Dharma, so you may stay as you wish. We have already selected the best rooms for the World-Honored One, and the rest have been divided into four parts as before, with no bedding for visiting monks.
Then ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana went to the World-Honored One, bowed at his feet, and sat to one side. They reported this matter in detail to the World-Honored One.
The World-Honored One gathered the assembly of monks because of this matter and said:

This four-part property belongs to the Saá¹…gha of the four directions. It should not be divided, should not be appropriated by oneself, should not be bought or sold, and is not sold by the Saá¹…gha, not by many people, up to not by one person.

If that Saá¹ƒgha, many people, or one person, themselves enter, divide, or sell and buy it, it does not count as their own entry, it does not count as divided, it does not count as sold and bought, and they commit a thullaccaya offense.
What are the four directions' Saá¹ƒgha's belongings?

The Saá¹ƒgha's monastery, the monastery's belongings, and the individual rooms' belongings - this is the first part of the four directions' Saá¹ƒgha's belongings. It should not be divided, should not be entered by oneself, and should not be sold and bought. Whether it is the Saá¹ƒgha, many people, or one person, they should not divide it, should not enter it by themselves, and should not sell and buy it.

If the Saá¹ƒgha, many people, or one person, divides it, enters it by themselves, or sells and buys it, it does not count as divided, it does not count as entered by oneself, it does not count as sold and bought, and they commit a thullaccaya offense.
The second and third are also like this.
